awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How do predators spread disease? Tests of five ecological and eco-evolutionary mechanisms with disease in the plankton
awd_abstract_narration:
A practical goal of disease ecologists is to find ways to stop or slow the spread of infection from host to host. A popular idea is that predators control disease outbreaks by killing infected prey which are weaker and thereby easier to capture. However, this proposal warns that predators may sometimes spread disease in host populations. The researchers will use organisms living in lakes to test five ways in which predators could spread disease. These ideas are that predators: (1) while eating prey, physically spread parasites into prey habitat; (2) can increase food supply for prey, and more food can cause higher parasite production within infected hosts; (3) can shift the composition of prey populations towards certain ages and sizes that get infected more easily; (4) can kill other species that control disease; and (5) can cause genetic changes to prey populations, making them more susceptible to disease organisms. The project will focus on water fleas (the hosts), a deadly fungal parasite, and an insect predator to test these possibilities. The research uses these organisms as a model system: outbreaks of this fungus can be sampled in lakes, created in experiments within lakes and in the lab, and can be understood using mathematical models. These new ideas, once tested thoroughly in the lab and verified in nature, will help managers make prudent decisions on how to control disease outbreaks in wild and domestic animal populations. The project will train many students, and focus on engaging those in underrepresented groups.
 
This project integrates three approaches. First, it will invest in a survey of fungal epidemics in water flea hosts in 40 lakes. The data from this large survey will be used to generate complex statistical models that test the first four mechanisms (ideas) given above. Second, it uses controlled experiments. One experiment will test mechanisms (2)-(4) with factorial manipulation of predatory insects and "competitor-diluters" (other water flea species which eat parasite propagules). A second experiment will investigate details of mechanisms (1)-(3). A third experiment investigates a tradeoff among clonal genotypes of the host; genotypes which better escape predation are more vulnerable to parasites. The hypothesis is that predators will shift host populations, via rapid evolution, towards bigger epidemics via this tradeoff. Third, this project develops a new suite of parameterized, mathematical (dynamical) models, designed to evaluate each of the mechanisms separately and together.

por.por_cntn:
As rates of parasitism increase worldwide, there is substantial interest in understanding the factors that influence the prevalence of parasites and the impact they have on host populations. One idea that has received substantial interest is that predators can help protect populations of their prey from the harmful effects of virulent parasites. This idea, which has come to be known as the ‘healthy herds hypothesis’, is intuitive: many people think that lions, for example, make their prey populations stronger and fitter. However, the evidence that predators reduce parasitism in their prey is mixed, and there is very little evidence that prey densities increase as a result of predators reducing infection levels (which is what the healthy herds hypothesis posits). This is concerning because manipulating predator abundance has been proposed as a conservation strategy. 

One key outcome from this project was an experimental test of the healthy herds hypothesis, using an ecologically important and experimentally tractable predator-prey-parasite system. In this study, we found that predators reduced infection levels in their prey, supporting the first part of the healthy herds hypothesis. However, even though they had lower levels of a virulent parasite, the populations that experienced the highest predation levels were also the smallest. This means that our experiment did not support the second half of the healthy herds hypothesis (which predicts that predators should increase prey abundance by removing virulent parasites). This has important conservation implications, since it suggests that increase predation as a means of conserving a population of concern might backfire, driving lower population size.

Another major theme of research on this grant has been understanding the impact of different diets on the outcome of host-parasite interactions. We found that certain diets can protect hosts against infections with a virulent fungal parasite, and that this occurs because the parasite spores are unable to successfully enter the host’s body cavity when they prey on those protective diets. We also found that the resource environment is associated with shifts from parasitism (where the host suffers as a result of infection) to mutualism (where the host benefits from infection). This provides a rare example of a shift along the parasitism-mutualism gradient in a natural population.

This project also explored how predators feed on infected hosts. In a series of studies, we found that infected hosts are more susceptible to predation by fish (which are visual predators) and midge larvae (which are tactile predators). This likely results from a combination of changes in their appearance (changes in transparency and color) and from changes in swimming behavior (most notably, a decrease in swimming speed).

Sixteen undergraduates worked on this project. Some of these students are coauthors on manuscripts that have been published (1 student), are in review (2 students) or in preparation (1 student). We anticipate that at least two additional students will be coauthors on manuscripts that are not yet in preparation. Of these sixteen undergraduates, ten are from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences (e.g., first generation student, military veteran, and/or racial or ethnic minority). This grant also supported four postdoctoral scholars, two graduate students, and two research technicians. Of the postdoctoral scholars, two have moved on to faculty positions, one to a position at a public health agency, and the fourth is still a postdoc. Of the graduate students, one has moved on to a postdoctoral position and will begin a faculty position next year; the other is nearing the completion of her PhD. Of the two research technicians, one is currently working as a nurse and the other is in medical school.

We also led outreach events related to this project. This included: leading and running a week-long course on data literacy for high school students from Ypsilanti, Detroit, and Southfield, MI; developing and leading activities for middle school girls from Ann Arbor, Detroit, and Ypsilanti; helping to organize and participate in a scientist spotlight event held at a Spanish language school; and helping to organize and run a BioBlitz in Detroit.

Seven publications from this work have already appeared in print, with an additional publication under review. Several other publications are currently in preparation for submission, and more will be prepared in the future.
